titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Reuben Fenner habeas corpus writ and affidavit 1977.418
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-11-28 21:34:28 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Reuben Fenner habeas corpus writ and affidavit
did.abstract: This collection consists of an 1814 writ of habeas corpus and affidavit addressed to Lieutenant Colonel Forbes, commander of the 42nd Regiment of the New York State Militia at Fort Lewis in New Utrecht, Kings County, regarding the release of Reuben Fenner, who enlisted under age.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The two documents in this collection are housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Reuben Fenner habeas corpus writ and affidavit, 1977.418, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level. This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a writ of habeas corpus and an affidavit addressed to Lieutenant Colonel Forbes, commander of the 42nd Regiment of the New York State Militia at Fort Lewis in New Utrecht, Kings County, regarding the release of Reuben Fenner, who enlisted under age. The documents are dated October 14, 1814.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The material in this collection is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
